repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Changes to Numpy module to use their C API rather than the
internal data structure mean that more things crash if `import_array`
isn't called.

For the discussion in https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3520
it sounds like it's worth doing _something_ to alert people to this.
This PR adds a call to _import_array in the module initialization.

I've added it to GilCheck (just because that's at the end of the
pipeline) however it could go elsewhere if there's a transform
suitable.

I wonder if it might be worthwhile to add a `no_import_array`
empty call to indicate "I'm deliberately not calling import_array.
I know what I'm doing. Don't warn." I haven't done this here but
it could be easily added.

There are cases when `import_array` isn't necessary (e.g. just using `np.uint64_t` or similar). I haven't attempted to detect these, and I don't think it's worthwhile trying to.

comment_data.body: Is `or` correct here? If either of the two _is_ used, we should not generate the call.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3021,6 +3021,28 @@ def visit_Node(self, node):
             node.in_nogil_context = True
         return node
 
+    def visit_ModuleNode(self, node):
+        # Not strictly a GIL check however check to see if numpy import_array is called
+        # should probably be done as late as possible
+        for mod in node.scope.cimported_modules:
+            if mod.name == "numpy":
+                import_array = mod.lookup_here("import_array")
+                _import_array = mod.lookup_here("_import_array")
+                if ((import_array and not import_array.used)
+                        or (_import_array and not _import_array.used)):

comment_data.body: For users cimporting anything other than "numpy" here, this message seems more confusing than helpful. Do we need to warn about this at all?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3021,6 +3021,28 @@ def visit_Node(self, node):
             node.in_nogil_context = True
         return node
 
+    def visit_ModuleNode(self, node):
+        # Not strictly a GIL check however check to see if numpy import_array is called
+        # should probably be done as late as possible
+        for mod in node.scope.cimported_modules:
+            if mod.name == "numpy":
+                import_array = mod.lookup_here("import_array")
+                _import_array = mod.lookup_here("_import_array")
+                if ((import_array and not import_array.used)
+                        or (_import_array and not _import_array.used)):
+                    # sanity check that this is actually numpy and not a user pxd called "numpy"
+                    if _import_array and _import_array.type.is_cfunction:
+                        # warning is mainly for the sake of testing
+                        warning(node.pos, "'numpy.import_array()' has been added automatically "
+                                "since 'numpy' was cimported but 'numpy.import_array' was not called.", 0)
+                        node.scope.use_utility_code(
+                                UtilityCode.load_cached("NumpyImportArray", "NumpyImportArray.c")
+                            )
+                    else:
+                        warning(node.pos, "A module named 'numpy' was cimported but 'import_array' was "
+                                "not available.", 1)

comment_data.body:
`//` is not a valid comment in C89.
```suggestion
    static void** _check_array_api(void) {
        return PyArray_API; /* should be non NULL */
```

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,15 @@
+///////////////////////// NumpyImportArray.init ////////////////////
+
+// comment below is deliberately kept in the generated C file to
+// help users debug where this came from:
+/*
+ * Cython has automatically inserted a call to _import_array since
+ * you didn't include one when your cimported numpy. To disable this
+ * add the line
+ *   <void>_import_array
+ */
+#ifdef NPY_NDARRAYOBJECT_H /* numpy headers have been included */
+#if !NO_IMPORT_ARRAY /* can be explicitly set to tell Numpy its initialization is done manually */

comment_data.body:
> `__PYX_ERR(1, 1, __pyx_L1_error)`

We can pass this in from `code.error_goto(…)` and use Tempita utility code generation for it. That may seem overhead for such a simple thing, but we avoid knowing the details here that are otherwise hidden behind the code writer everywhere else.

Also, I think this code should do what `import_array()` does, i.e. make sure it raises `ImportError` on failure and nothing else.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,15 @@
+///////////////////////// NumpyImportArray.init ////////////////////
+
+// comment below is deliberately kept in the generated C file to
+// help users debug where this came from:
+/*
+ * Cython has automatically inserted a call to _import_array since
+ * you didn't include one when your cimported numpy. To disable this
+ * add the line
+ *   <void>_import_array
+ */
+#ifdef NPY_NDARRAYOBJECT_H /* numpy headers have been included */
+#if !NO_IMPORT_ARRAY /* can be explicitly set to tell Numpy its initialization is done manually */
+if (_import_array() == -1) __PYX_ERR(1, 1, __pyx_L1_error) /* __pyx_L1_error reliably exists in __Pyx_InitGlobals */

comment_data.body:
I wonder if it's enough to add the helper function to [`utility_code_for_cimports`](https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/188ca7f9b873dc8b702a704da9ea83299a4e1f29/Cython/Compiler/Nodes.py#L8147-L8153) ?
You may have to pass `env` in there (to access `env.global_scope()`), but that should be ok, I think. (And you may also need `code` for the `error_goto()`…)

comment_data.body: `utility_code_for_cimports` is called during the AnalyseDeclarations phase, so we definitely haven't got `code`. We also haven't got the `entry.used` values set. I see the appeal of putting it there, but it doesn't really fit with how it currently works. It's not impossible though - would just need things moving around a bit.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
        used = (import_array and import_array.used) or (_import_array and _import_array.used)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -8159,6 +8159,36 @@ def cython_view_utility_code():
     'inspect': ("__Pyx_patch_inspect", "PatchInspect", "Coroutine.c"),
 }
 
+def cimport_numpy_check(node, code):
+    # shared code between CImportStatNode and FromCImportStatNode
+    # check to ensure that import_array is called
+    if node.module_name != "numpy":
+        return
+    for mod in code.globalstate.module_node.scope.cimported_modules:
+        if mod.name != node.module_name:
+            continue
+        # there are sometimes several cimported modules with the same name
+        # so complete the loop if necessary
+        import_array = mod.lookup_here("import_array")
+        _import_array = mod.lookup_here("_import_array")
+        # at least one entry used
+        used = ((import_array.used if import_array else False)
+                or (_import_array.used if _import_array else False))

comment_data.body: Not at all, no. I was thinking that a) we use `unlikely()` (almost) wherever we do exception handling, so why not here, and b) it can have an impact on code layout. I don't want the C compiler to draw unlucky conclusions about the amount of space and memory pages to allocate to the module init function, so more hints about what will be used can't really hurt.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,20 @@

+#ifdef NPY_NDARRAYOBJECT_H /* numpy headers have been included */
+// NO_IMPORT_ARRAY is Numpy's mechanism for indicating that import_array is handled elsewhere
+#if !NO_IMPORT_ARRAY /* https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-1.17.0/reference/c-api.array.html#c.NO_IMPORT_ARRAY  */
+if (_import_array() == -1) {

comment_data.body: Yes - those tests were actually failing so good catch. The `FromCImportStatNode` nodes were being dropped in `MarkParallelAssignments` - (I think unintentionally)

I'm added a more detailed exception message. I think this is worthwhile because the user didn't call it so it may not be obvious where it came from.

I could see this exception being raised occasionally if people are writing packages that just uses the numpy headers for typedefs like `uint32_t`, and then distributing the compiled modules believing there's no dependence on Numpy.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,21 @@
+///////////////////////// NumpyImportArray.init ////////////////////
+
+// comment below is deliberately kept in the generated C file to
+// help users debug where this came from:
+/*
+ * Cython has automatically inserted a call to _import_array since
+ * you didn't include one when you cimported numpy. To disable this
+ * add the line
+ *   <void>numpy._import_array
+ */
+#ifdef NPY_NDARRAYOBJECT_H /* numpy headers have been included */
+// NO_IMPORT_ARRAY is Numpy's mechanism for indicating that import_array is handled elsewhere
+#if !NO_IMPORT_ARRAY /* https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-1.17.0/reference/c-api.array.html#c.NO_IMPORT_ARRAY  */
+if (unlikely(_import_array() == -1)) {
+    PyErr_SetString(PyExc_ImportError, "numpy.core.multiarray failed to import "
+    "(auto-generated because you didn't call 'numpy.import_array()' after cimporting numpy; "
+    "use '<void>numpy._import_array' to disable if you are certain you don't need it).");

commit.message:
Added warnings for cimport numpy without import_array

Changes to Numpy module to use their C API rather than the
internal data structure mean that more things crash if `import_array`
isn't called.

For the discussion in https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3520
it sounds like it's worth doing _something_ to alert people to this.
It also sounds like implicitly adding `import_array` isn't the
best idea. Therefore this PR adds a warning. It can always be
reverted if a better option is found.

I've added it to GilCheck (just because that's at the end of the
pipeline) however it could go elsewhere if there's a transform
suitable.

I wonder if it might be worthwhile to add a `no_import_array`
empty call to indicate "I'm deliberately not calling import_array.
I know what I'm doing. Don't warn." I haven't done this here but
it could be easily added.
Updated to autogenerate call to import_array

Switched back to _import_array

(builtins aren't initialized in time to use the Cython import_array
version)

Apply suggestions from code review

Co-Authored-By: Stefan Behnel <stefan_ml@behnel.de>

commit.message:
Added extra tests and fixed from numpy cimport ...

Also added a bit more detail to the exception.

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Make cimport numpy without import_array safer
